pullRequest.title: Introduce token-backed (KeyStore-backed) JSSKeyManager
pullRequest.bodyText:
This introduces KeyStore-backed JSSKeyManagers. We:

Make JSSKeyManager an interface, allowing multiple implementations and making it easier to detect a compatible KeyManager,
Add the new KeyStore-backed JSSTokenKeyManager (this name comes from the fact that a KeyStore wraps an individual token). This falls back to CryptoManager when no KeyStore instance has been provided.
Since KeyStore is already tested, we just need to test the factory construction &c; we modify an existing test pass in TestSSLEngine to use the new initialization routines.

nodes.bodyText: This is from the existing code, but it's probably not necessary since all classes implementing the org.mozilla.jss.crypto.X509Certificate are subclasses of PK11Cert.

beforeCommit.message:
Add test for Token-based KeyManager

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

afterCommit.message:
Add test for Token-based KeyManager

Into the JSSEngine tests, we introduce an additional path which uses the
new JSSTokenKeyManager both with the KeyStore and without it.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

This line can be removed. We can use the cm field.

commit.message:
Split JSSKeyManager interface, implementation

JSSKeyManager extends X509KeyManager and provides one additional call
that is used by JSSEngine. We also introduce a token-backed KeyManager,
using the existing KeyStore API. When no KeyStore is provided, this
KeyManager falls back to loading certificates from the CryptoManager,
matching existing behavior.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>

Add test for Token-based KeyManager

Into the JSSEngine tests, we introduce an additional path which uses the
new JSSTokenKeyManager both with the KeyStore and without it.

Signed-off-by: Alexander Scheel <ascheel@redhat.com>
